title: Colorado theater shooting: Obama urges Americans to focus on victims
content:
Barack Obama meets with with Jordan Ghawi ( @ JordanGhawi ) brother of Jessica Ghawi , the aspiring sports broadcaster who died in the shooting . | Photo courtesy of @ PeterBurnsRadio Obama urges focus on victims
AURORA , Colo. — President Barack Obama on Sunday urged Americans to focus on the victims , rather than the suspect , from Friday ’ s movie theater shooting as he spoke of national solidarity in the wake of the incident .
“ Although the perpetrator of this evil act has received a lot of attention over the last couple of days , that attention will fade away , and in the end after he has felt the full force of our justice system , what will be remembered are the good people who were impacted by this tragedy , ” the president said , in brief remarks after spending close to three hours meeting with victims and family members at the University of Colorado Hospital here .
“ I hope that over the next several days , next several weeks and next several months , we all reflect on how we can do something about some of the senseless violence that ends up marring this country , ” he said , skirting the reemerging debate about gun control policy . The coming days , he added , should also be a chance to “ reflect on all the wonderful people who make this the greatest country on earth . ”
The president came to meet with victims ’ families and local officials in an effort to show his support without being a distraction in the aftermath of a rampage that killed 12 and injured 58 . He was joined by the state ’ s Democratic governor , John Hickenlooper , and senators , Mark Udall and Michael Bennet , as well as Aurora Mayor Steve Hogan and other local officials .
Twenty-three people were brought to the University of Colorado Hospital , a five-minute drive from the Century 16 movie theater where the shootings took place early Friday morning . One died , while most of those brought to the hospital had been shot . Ten patients are still hospitalized . Seven are in critical condition and three in good condition , a hospital spokesman said . Their names haven ’ t been released .
Obama ’ s stop in the Denver suburb came less than three days after a bloody shooting spree at the start of a midnight Friday showing of “ The Dark Knight Rises , ” the latest movie in the Batman franchise . Those killed ranged in age from 6 to 51 .
James Holmes , 24 , is in custody and is to make an initial court appearance Monday . The Associated Press reported Sunday that he is not cooperating with authorities .
Obama described his meetings with family members as a chance for them “ to describe how wonderful their brother or their son or daughter was and the lives that they had touched and the dreams that they held for the future , ” he said , biting his lip . “ I confessed to them that words are always inadequate in these kinds of situations but that my main task was to serve as a representative of the entire country and let them know that we are thinking about them at this moment and will continue to think about them each and every day . ”
“ The awareness that not only all of America but much of the world is thinking about them might serve as some comfort , ” he said .
